direction.raw_text: smashing into the mud, as a football OFFENSIVE LINE comes set, frosted breath steaming across to: The DEFENSIVE LINE digging in, ready to explode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S.U. quarterback, barking signals. The ball is snapped, and we go to SLOW MOTION as the lines crash together in the slop. Joe rolls to the right, looking downfield. A huge DEFENSIVE END bears down on him. Joe jukes. The end whips on by, grabbing for jersey, slipping off. But big NUMBER 75 is closing the gap. On the run, Joe releases a desperation pass toward the end zone, just as 75 catches him and buries him face-down in the swamp. We FOLLOW THE BALL, spiraling through the slanting rain. RAY GRIFFEN, black running back, glances back for it, two DEFENSIVE BACKS with him. All three leap in unison, climbing as high as they can, clutching, clawing for the ball. The ball floats down, kisses off the tangle of fingers, splashes to the ground, and rolls to a stop in the mud. Incomplete. The BANG of the final gun snaps us back to LIVE ACTION. Joe on his knees in the muck, stares at the goal line, then drops his head in defeat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betraying little emotion, Coach SAM WINTERS, wiry, intense, early 50's, takes off his headset, lets it drop, heads across the field.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 (V.O.) Coach, this is the second year in a row you've failed to go to a bowl game. Do you feel your program's in decline?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Coach Winters stands outside his office surrounded by reporters, a bouquet of microphones stuck in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elsewhere in the locker room, we pick up a weary, mud- splattered Joe Kane taking off his pads in front of his locker. ALVIN MACK, black linebacker, comes by. Alvin exudes danger; big, fast and hostile on the field, slightly surly, a sense of repressed anger off it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (keeping his cool) No, we're just a young team on the verge. We'll be back in a major bowl next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good throw, Joe. It was there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So was half their team. (trailing off) Shit, another Christmas at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next year, man. Next year we sell out. Next year we dominate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: still fielding questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Winters gets up to go, we hear:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #2 You still need a deep threat or a breakaway back to go with Joe Kane. What are you gonna do to address this need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little edgy) Stop wastin' my time talkin' to you guys for a start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm not gonna lead you into the fog here, Sam...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: grey-haired eminence, sits behind his desk. Seated across from him are Coach Winters and GALEN HOWARD, 50, the Athletic Director.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilson points to a representation of a football field affixed to the wall. A football rests on the 40 yard line, which is marked 160 million. The end zone (60 yards away) is $400,000,000.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm concerned about our Program. It's always been a source of pride to our students and alumni, but two straight so-so seasons are having a damaging effect on our fund-raising, both public and private.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (half-joking) Then stop raising the entrance requirements on me. We never could have gotten Alvin Mack in here under the new guidelines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As Chancellor, my first responsibility is to the academic interests of this University.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At a time when we're committed to a 400 million dollar building program, alumni donations are down 15% the last two years. Because they've also voiced their displeasure to their legislators, we can expect a corresponding drop in state funds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Athletic Fund is suffering too. Season tickets sales are off, merchandising's slow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You layin' all this at my door? There's been a recession on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but the heaviest drop has been from the big donors, the 100,000 dollar club. These people are recession proof. They sit in my box every game, and they're much more generous when we're ranked and going to bowl games. Two of them, as you know, are on the Board of Regents, including the Chairman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you trying to say to me, Grant? After 12 years, my job's in jeopardy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not prepared to discuss your job right now; I just want you to be aware of the situation. The alumni and the legislature are unhappy and they vote with their checkbooks. I don't pretend to be an expert on football, Sam, and I'll deny that this conversation ever took place, but I do know we need to win next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Coach Winters flanked by two assistant coaches, HUMES and CLAYTON, walks down a cavernous tunnel beneath the stands to a waiting car. At the end of the tunnel, a scarecrow EFFIGY of Coach Winters hangs from an overhead pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coach Winters stops, looks up at the effigy. Humes and Clayton fear an outburst, a display of rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. He strides on. Humes and Clayton race to catch up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring the effigy) Tickets are in your coat. Itinerary and player profiles are in your briefcase. We got a 9:00am tomorrow in Philly with this kid Darnell Jefferson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like I've lost weight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This kid's the gamebreaker we've been lookin' for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TITLES BEGIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boeing 737 roars into the night sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Had a 108 yard kickoff return against Taft. Michigan's been down to see him twice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LUKE'S HOME FOR BOYS - MORNING Winters, Humes, Clayton and Joe Kane sit across from DARNELL JEFFERSON and REVEREND WALLACE in a tattered parlor room. Other boys of various ages and color look in from the adjoining door. Darnell is black, good-looking, street-hip, the letters D.J. shaved in block letters into his fade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This gets a little chuckle from the Reverend. It was intended to.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Darnell, you have the potential to start for us as a freshman. That 108 yard kickoff return you made against Taft? One of the greatest runs I've ever seen a high school player make. Now, Michigan is set at tailback for two years. You won't play till you're a junior. With Joe here gettin' you the ball, runnin' 28 Thunder right, you'll be All-American with us as a Sophomore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but I'm really more concerned with Darnell's education. He came here late. He's got some catching up to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me, education is the first priority in our program. That's why all the players are smarter than me. After all, a football coach is smart enough to understand the game, but dumb enough to think it's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see a run-down tenant SHACK on the edge of a large cotton field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two rooms. Dirt floor. Two-foot Christmas tree on an apple cart. Alvin Mack's MOTHER opens a Christmas present as Alvin and his TWO SISTERS look on. It's an ENGRAVED LIONSHEAD DOORKNOCKER, the kind you'de find on the door of an affluent home. The inscription reads THE MACK'S. Alvin's mother thinks it's beautiful, but isn't sure what to do with it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's real pretty, Alvin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I turn pro, I'll get you the house to go with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Winters' daughter LOUANNE, 20, is on the phone with her father. Louanne is sexy, clothes too tight, but good-natured, somewhat needy and loyal as a labrador. She holds a hopelessly out-of-style sweater her dad's given her for Christmas.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (lying) It's real nice, Dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Winters sits on the bed, eating Chinese take-out, the phone cradled in his neck, talking to Louanne.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'de like it, Lou. Merry Christmas. Put some fresh flowers on your Mom's grave for me. I'll be home in a couple days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Battered and old, in a declining Pennsylvania neighborhood, hard by a STEEL WORKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe sits on the couch with his older brother, FRANK, watching the bowl game he would have been in, had E.S.U. won their last game. His FATHER, a grizzled man in his fifties, nods in and out in a tattered armchair. All three have been drinking beer, their empties scattered around. Frank tosses Joe an Iron City beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Joe's father heads for the kitchen, he hangs his empty beer can, by the pull tab, on a branch of the Christmas tree. We see that the whole tree is covered with cans.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have another Vitamin I, Joey. Didn't think we'de see you here this Christmas, little brother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up) Yeh, well we won't rent your place on the couch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PHILADELPHIA BOY'S HOME - NIGHT Darnell talks on a pay phone in the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're from E.S.U?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh. I was just sittin' here by the fire doin' my homework, and decided to give you a call. See how you're doin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .S.U. ATHLETIC DEPARTMENT - NIGHT We see who Darnell is talking to: AUTUMN HALEY, beautiful black girl, stylish, long straight hair, definitely not street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We PULL BACK and REVEAL Autumn in an office with 15 other telephones, a coed on every one. ASST. COACH MYERS supervises with a clipboard of names and numbers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Coach Winters has been telling me about you. I'm looking forward to seeing you when you come to visit. I'll be your guide. You are coming to visit aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Joe leads Darnell down to the end of the tunnel, where Autumn is waiting. He introduces them. She's even more attractive than Darnell thought she'd be. She takes Darnell's hand and leads him out onto the field where he's greeted by the E.S.U. BAND playing the school fight song. The CHEERLEADERS whip into action, legs kicking, pom-poms whirling. The band parts and Darnell walks out into the 90,000 seat stadium, an awesome sight for any young man. Autumn points to the giant DIAMOND VISION SCOREBOARD. Darnell's name and picture appear. The stadium P.A. ANNOUNCER cuts in. P.A. ANNOUNCER Now for the starting line-up for the E.S.U. Timber Wolves. At tailback, number 20, Darnell Jefferson!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell, in his excitement, does a little end-zone dance. Slaps hands with Joe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You got that right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Romantic, Ivy-League look, lit by soft-glo footlights. Darnell and Autumn walk, side by side, stopping outside Autumn's dorm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans down to kiss her. She hesitates, not sure about this, then comes forward, kisses him on the lips, starts to let it deepen, then breaks it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he watches her go up the steps, we go to:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for showin' me around, Autumn. I don't meet too many females like you. You got a lotta class. Real efficacious. Maybe I'll check you out in the fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope so, Darnell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE BOYS HOME - DAY Early February: It's National Decision Day and Darnell's home is under seige. Reporters. Microphones. Television cameras. Darnell steps out onto the porch wearing an ESU jersey with #1 emblazoned on it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now you know where I'm going and what we're indubitably going to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and TITLES END.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S.U. CAMPUS - DAY A hot, late summer day. Over the deserted Quad, we see the title: 6 MONTHS LATER. It fades and we MOVE TO REVEAL a city BUS pulling up at a curb adjacent to the Quad. Off steps Darnell, carrying one battered suitcase. Joe Kane and BUD LITE KAMINSKY, offensive line tackle, are there to greet him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Darnell, Welcome to E.S.U.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking hands) Yeh, good to see you guys. What happened to the band and the dancin' honies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Regular students don't come back for two weeks yet. Not that they woulda been here. Now that you've enrolled, you're just another wormshit freshman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A dorm devoted exclusively to football players. Luxurious lounges, study halls, saunas, recreation and media rooms. Spacious living quarters. A world unto itself. Joe and Bud usher Darnell into his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell looks around, taking it all in. He tries to be cool, but this is easily the nicest room he's ever had.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe and Bud start down the hall. Darnell turns back into his room, then starts to pace off it's dimensions, heel to toe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here's your room. If you need anything call the hall manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See ya later. Freshman Placement test tomorrow at nine. McKinnley Hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: College hang-out, bar, catering to athletes and their admirers. A black HARLEY DAVIDSON, driven by Joe Kane with Darnell on the back, pulls up at the curb. They get off, head inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe and Darnell pass a table of three girls, conspicuous among them is Louanne Winters. Joe and Darnell give her a nod and proceed on to a table where three fellow players wait: Bud Lite, BOBBY COLLINS, good-looking, silver-tongued ladies man and 2nd string quarterback, and STEVE LATTIMER, heavily muscled, surf-punk defensive end. Between them is a large pitcher of beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud takes a good-natured swipe at him. Lattimer deflects it. Joe notices Bobby looking over at Louanne. She gives Bobby a surreptitious little wave to come over and sit with her. He gives her the "just a minute" sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby laughs and heads over to Louanne's table, as Joe pours himself another beer. Alvin enters the bar, goes to Joe's table, plops a copy of Sports Illustrated down in front of Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the cover is a picture of Joe and ONE OTHER QUARTERBACK, TIM WAYMEN. The coverline reads, HEISMAN HOPEFULS: THE YEAR OF THE QUARTERBACK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe stares at the cover. He's more stunned than elated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe drains his beer, pours another. Lattimer starts to read form the article.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muted chuckles, but set faces. The challenge accepted. Joe chugs his beer, pours another.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, oh, the Lead Dog is back. There goes my cover of the media guide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Bobby, Lats, how ya doin? This is Darnell Jefferson, freshman tailback.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How ya' doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was hopin' you'de have rolled your bike or somethin'. Nothin' serious, just enough to keep you out for the season.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pouring himself some beer) No such luck, Backup Man. But I'll try to engineer a few blowouts. Get you get some mop-up time. (studying Lattimer) Shit, Lats, you look buffed, man. You put on some weight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: lbs. Spent the summer in the gym. I'm tired of watchin' you guys play. I intend to start this year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You get any bigger, you can play offense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, but don't I have to get dumber too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You still seein' Louanne?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh. Now and then, when the tide rises. Don't want her to think this is some kind've exclusive deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coach finds out you're nailin' his daughter, you'll be playin' dorm ball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bail before that. Besides, this is what he gets for not startin' me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, man, you seen this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ribbing Joe) You must be some very bad-ass motherfucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? You didn't know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew there was gonna be an article. I didn't know it was gonna be on the cover.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit, we do all the work. You get all the pub. Too bad we're not allowed to hit you in practice. Be fun to kick the shit out of a Heisman Trophy Candidate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess you'll have to wait till we get to the pros.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Darnell) Beer boy, get me some.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it look like I'm serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to this. "E.S.U. has a solid nucleus returning, but the Timberwolves, coming off two disappointing seasons, will only go as far as the strong right arm of Heisman Candidate Joe Kane will take them." That right, Joe? You gonna lead us to the promised land?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna lead... but can you follow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The crowd from the 911 (Bud, Alvin, Lattimer, Darnell, Bobby and Louanne) follow Joe down the hill behind the bar toward a busy two-lane highway. Joe, a little drunker than the others, starts HOWLING at the moon like a Timber Wolf. The others join in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Joe makes a dash out onto the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe stands on the white line, cars and trucks whizzing by, then lies down on his back, arms at his side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are we doin', Joe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly slurred) There's something I wanta try. Gotta wake up our Mojo. Start settin' the tone for the season.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not a good time to be settin' anything. You're in no shape...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joe, c'mon Joe, don't be an asshole. Joe! God-damnit, why's he always doin' shit like this? Coach'll fuckin' kill me. Alvin, go get him, will ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell no, you go get his ass. Crazy motherfucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cars and trucks blast toward us, roar on by, right on top of us, honking, spraying grime, shaking the asphalt. Bud and the others on the side of the road are increasingly worried now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pissed off, Bud sprints out to the white line. The draft- wake of a passing truck almost blows him over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud hesitates a second, scared, but stung by this dare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bud can't fight it. He lies down on the line, his head touching Joe's feet. Joe begins to HOWL again. Bud joins in. Alvin and the others can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby and Lattimer look at each other a beat. Time to ante up. Both turn to Alvin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alvin snorts in disgust and starts out onto the blacktop. Bobby and Lattimer smile, go to follow. Louanne grabs Bobby, holds him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby smiles, grabs her ass, pulls her to him, gives her a long, passionate kiss, then sprints out to the white line, leaving her breathless. Alvin, Bobby and Lattimer lie down in front of Bud. Now there's a line of five, a human highway median. Everybody scared shitless, howling their lungs out. Louanne and Darnell watch from the side of the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, Joe laughing wildly, jumps up and they all scramble back to safety. Out of breath, but pumped up, they exchange exhilarated high fives. Alvin just shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck this shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Joe, that's enough. Let's get the hell outa here. What if somebody drifts or crosses the line to pass?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Bud? Can't you follow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (torn) God-damnit, god-damnit. Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Startin' to look like a loaf of Wonder bread out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're makin' us look like pussies, ya know. Standin' here suckin' our thumbs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Alvin) Yeh, and there's nobody from the Defense out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you lookin' at? You think you're bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely sexual) Bobby, be careful, o.k? Please, be careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This guy do this kinda shit a lot? They never mentioned this in recruiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Twenty freshman football players, including Darnell, are scattered at tables around the room, writing furiously in test booklets, as a PROCTOR paces the room. Darnell starts to write an answer, stops, stumped. Worried, he looks at the clock, goes on to the next page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S.U. CAMPUS - MORNING Darnell and Joe walk across campus. Darnell carries a gleaming, chromed TROPHY with a football player on top. He's still thinking about the test.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Darnell sees Autumn walking across the Quad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe starts to protest, but Darnell is already off, racing across the Quad, quickly catching up with Autumn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, slightly embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts walking away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She speeds up. He speeds up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's just about to say something when RAY GRIFFEN arrives. Ray's the starting tailback, black, handsome, clean-cut, well-spoken, middle class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is exactly what Autumn didn't want to happen. Ray and Darnell eye each other like a couple of roosters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Autumn can't believe he said this. She starts to interject something to break the tension, but never gets the chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Autumn's mortification is complete.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I left a lot of 'em blank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, you'll do all right. Lotta people don't finish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not convinced) Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doin' with the trophy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coach Winters asked me to bring it to the meeting. I don't know what for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see ya at the meeting. (handing him the trophy) Take this for me, will ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Autumn, hold up! What're you doing here? I thought students didn't come back for two weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rather coolly) I came back early to see a friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're looking fresh, Autumn. A package of pulchritudiness. What about getting together later tonight? Maybe get a pizza? They got pizza in this town don't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about tomorrow night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think it's a real good idea for us to see each other, Darnell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? I'm not good enough for you all of a sudden? Too young, is that it? I'm not, ya know. They held me back a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's not that... I've got a boyfriend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you have this boyfriend when you showed me around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctant to admit it) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, it didn't seem to bother you then. I'm willing to overlook it now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was mad at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I caught him with another girl. A white girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're still with this nigger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I got to get going, Darnell. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to lead you on. I'm glad you came here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute. I can at least walk with you, can't I? Nothin' wrong with that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in a hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can keep up. I run the forty in four-four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Autumn --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Ray. This is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cutting in, offering his hand) Darnell Jefferson. (pointedly) Tailback.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking Darnell's hand) Ray Griffen. (just as pointedly) Starting tailback.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. That's why they recruited me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The two guys they recruited before you are handing out Gatorade now. (making the jerkoff motion) Better start strengthening your wrist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll see. (departing, to Ray) Give my best to Miss Lilly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) What the hell is that supposed to mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .S.U. CAMPUS - DAY Establish the new, modern KELLER CENTER, home of the E.S.U. Athletic Department.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The football meeting room. A quarter amphitheatre. The Freshman, including Darnell, down in front. Nervous, talking very little, eyes playing over the pictures of former E.S.U. greats arranged on the Wall of Honor. Behind them, the Upperclassmen, bantering, conversation punctuated with laughter. A door opens. The Assistant Coaches file in. The room hushes immediately. Coach Winters walks in. The Upperclassmen break into applause; the Freshmen quickly take their cue and join in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The upperclassmen hoot, as Darnell, embarrassed, takes off his earring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The players nod reverentially at this established axiom of the football cannon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spreading smiles all around. It's good to be a football player.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The smiles are gone. Lots of set faces now. Shame. anger, retribution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The freshmen are hanging on every word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smashes the trophy on the podium, breaking it in half, shattering the base. Darnell and the other freshmen are agog. The upperclassmen stifle laughs, particularly Ray Griffen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The upperclassmen nod, steely, purposeful. We go to the freshmen. They're not so sure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good to see you again, gentlemen. (catching sight of Darnell) Jefferson, either take off the earring or put on a dress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanna talk a little about what we're trying to do here. There are many highly respected people who feel football is about preparation for life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These people are full of shit. You see, football is not like life. (pause) It's better. More exciting, more intense, more fun. In life, people are always wondering how they measure up; whether they're getting ahead or fallin' behind. In football, you know. Every week you get a chance to show what you're made of, a chance to demonstrate the physical and personal qualities that all those poor bastards who can't play this game are left to agonize about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last year we didn't make enough of those chances. Last year everyone felt we let the school down. Fuck the school. We let ourselves down. (pointing to the Wall of Honor) We let down a great tradition, a 120- year-old Line of Champions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any football program worth the name is a special brotherhood, an elite corps of warriors, a select group of knights. That first time our starting unit takes the field, the first time we huddle up; that's our inner circle, that's our Round Table. If I were an upperclassman, I'd be real nervous about my seat, cause we got some very talented new-comers this year. Guys who want a place at the Table. (producing Darnell's trophy from behind the podium) This is the trophy one of our freshman, Darnell Jefferson, won as a Pennsylvania State High School First Team All-American. You know what this says to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a god-damn thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the freshmen) Everybody here was a high school All- American. (to all the players) Whatever any of you have done before is out the window. We're startin' over. Ground zero. The Table is empty. Are you ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .S.U. PRACTICE FIELD - DAY Passing drills. Joe Kane takes a snap, fades to pass, throws an out. The ball sails two feet over the receiver's head. Joe's angry with himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Winters) He's too pumped up. Tryin' to win the damn Heisman on every throw. I'm not sure he's ready for all this hype.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little late to be worryin' about that. If we don't follow up the Sports Illustrated cover with something, it'll look like we didn't believe in our own player.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Joe's a tough kid. He'll be allright.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Scrimmage. Joe hands off to Darnell. He sweeps right, cuts it up, blows past the end. In a spectacular display of broken field running, Darnell breaks to the sideline, cuts back, eluding the corner back, and stiffarms the safety. Alvin, pursuing the play, finally tackles him from behind, stripping the ball at the same time. There's a wild scramble for the fumble. Darnell is crushed under the pile, as the defense recovers it, ruining an otherwise brilliant run. The players unpile to reveal Darnell, writhing on the ground, the wind knocked out of him. Ray Griffen runs by to take his place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scrimmage moves up 15 yards leaving Darnell behind. Winters sprints over to Lattimer, grabs him by the face mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lattimer nods chastised. Winters moves over to check on Darnell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters extends a hand. Darnell grabs it, struggles shakily to his feet
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters wheels off leaving a wobbly Darnell alone with his football.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, nice writhing, Jefferson. You got all the moves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting to the team) Allright, move it up. Let's go, 15 yards, run the next play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut the necktie tackle horseshit. You think you're in some kinda highlight reel? He left you huggin' air. Target his guts. Drive right through his abdomen. I wanta see snot bubbles in his nose. I wanta see shit in his underwear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You injured, Jefferson, or just hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gasping) What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're hurt, you can still play. If you're injured you can't. Are you hurt or are you injured?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'm just hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .k., then get up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice run. Think what it coulda done for us if we still had the ball. (handing him the ball) This is a football. I want you to carry it with you wherever you go. Never let it out of your sight. (to the rest of the team) Any of you see him on campus, take a swipe at the ball. Try to knock it out of his hands. Recover it. (to Darnell again) If anybody, but you, returns this ball to me, you'll wish you'de never been born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) This isn't gonna get it, goddamnit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Winters, mad as hell, is berating his assistant coaches who are sitting, cowed in his office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I see tackling, but I don't see hitting. I see effort, but I don't see ferocity. What do you think, they're gonna motivate themselves? Football's just a game to most of these kids. This is our program, our livelihood. It's our job to make them care as much about it as we do. Make them hate me if you have to. It'll bring them together, give them a focus. So get off your butts and put the fear of God in these guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dead tired players toweling off, dressing. The trainer's room is crowded with aching, cramped-up, contused players. Across the way, Lattimer lifts weights, alone in the weight room. Clayton and Humes consider this from outside Winters' office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters, who's heard all this, comes by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winters walks on into his office. Clayton nods, realizing this subject is now closed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shit, Lattimer's an animal all of a sudden. Benchin' 450. He's gotta be on somethin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, steroids? Why do you always think my guys are juicin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... he's on the punt team for three years, then gains 35 pounds of rip in one summer and an attitude to go with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not doctors, gentlemen. The NCAA has testing programs for this. Let's let them worry about it. (to Clayton) Besides, it's not that hard to put on 35 pounds in a summer, if you really hit the gym.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Darnell walks in, wrung out from the day's practice, stumbles to the bed where he sees something that stops him - lying there is his PENNSYLVANIA STATE ALL AMERICAN TROPHY. Coach Winters actually smashed a replica. A smile appears on Darnell's tired face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For football players only. Bud Lite moves through the cafeteria line.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What you got tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Choice of three entrees. Shrimp, lasagna, T-bone steak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tough choice. I'll take all three.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a surprise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at another table with Alvin and several other black players. Lattimer is the only white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell's stung by this. He'd like to think of himself as capable of more. Suddenly, Coach Winters appears at the door, a surprise visitor to the training table. All the players wearing baseball caps, quickly doff them. Winters is angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The players all look at each other, then reluctantly get up and change tables. Darnell sits next to Joe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coach Winters surveys the scene, sees that all the tables are integrated now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks on out. Immediately, the players begin to drift back to their old tables.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When do they give ya the scores on that Placement Test?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who cares? I flunked it three times, before I got in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long as you're in the program, they'll get you through. Maybe not with a degree, but they'll keep you eligible. Just don't do nothin' embarrassing they can't cover you for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, they even give Alvin copies of his tests in advance. He sells 'em for a hundred bucks a pop to people in his class. 'Course he's gotta have somebody read 'em to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you, doughboy. I can read. See that shoe? (points to his shoes) That says Nike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still don't wanna flunk that test. I wanta get a degree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think, nigger? You're gonna be on the Supreme Court? All you need to know is how to sign an N.F.L. contract.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you guys? You're supposed to be a team. Winning depends on thinking and acting and going to war together. But you don't even eat like a team. You eat like two teams. A white one and a black one. What do I have to do? Make out a seating chart? Now get up. Move around. Mix it up. Now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mock introduction) Hi there. Darnell Jefferson. I'm a young black man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, glad to meet ya. Joe Kane, Caucasian. So what doya think a that new Garth Brooks album?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love that motherfucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's more like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Joe, Bud Lite and Bobby Collins, all suffering from various aches and pains are getting Naperson and analgesic balm out of the non-prescription drug cabinet. Joe pops a Nap and looks across to the weight room where a stunning co-ed CAMILLE SCHAEFFER works a knee lift. Camille's the perfect marriage of Southern patrician beauty and athletic confirmation. Joe leaves the others, heads over, pokes his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille stops her knee lift, turns to Joe. We think she's going to fire on him. Wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille starts to walk away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How ya' doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little late to be workin' out, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a little edge) Only time I could get in here when the football team wasn't usin' it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to get a rise out of her) Well, if it wasn't for the football team, might not be a weight room to use. You tryin' to firm up a little, or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unfazed) Don't need to firm up. I'm strengthening my knee. Had arthroscopic surgery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Had my knee scoped once too. When you're finished here, maybe we could get a yogurt, compare scars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, I don't date football players. They're all full of themselves. I saw you on the cover of Sports Illustrated, so you're probably worse than most.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's real open minded of you. So you won't consider doin' anything with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well at least tell me what happened to your knee. What'd you do? Fall outa your convertible?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, there's maybe one thing I'd do with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tennis. I'll play tennis with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tennis. You mean now? It's raining.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TENNIS COURTS - NIGHT smashing a two-fisted forehand right at us, grunting with the exertion. Joe scrambles to get it back, but Camille's a world-class player. She attacks with a vengeance, blasting every shot ala Jimmy Connors, as Bud Lite and Bobby Collins watch, amazed. We begin a SERIES OF CUTS detailing Camille's relentless dismantling of Joe: Camille drilling a backhand down the line, Joe barely getting it back to the net. Camille hitting a powerhouse service ace, Joe lunging and whiffing the return. Camille crushing another forehand. Joe crushes it back, sends it over the fence and into the parking lot. Camille serving again at match point. Joe pops up a weak return. Camille puts it away with a powerhouse overhead, the ball almost knocking Joe down. He flings his racket against the fence. Camille comes to the net to shake hands, but Joe hangs back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she walks away along to the net. Joe goes after her, pissed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille's taken aback, not realizing she'd struck a nerve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Joe walks away and Camille goes after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille considers, tries to figure out what she'd dislike least, knowing it'd be cheap to choose neither.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille walks off, disappearing through the gate. Joe walks off in the other direction. Bud Lite and Bobby follow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the game, Heisman. You took it really well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this Heisman crap?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say anything about being a Heisman candidate. I don't go around strokin' myself about it. So what's this shit you're givin' me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... I'm sorry... I just figured you were probably kissin' yourself in the mirror every morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You figured wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what do you want, an apology? I just gave you one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want a rematch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A rematch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some other sport. I took my beating. You owe me one. Either that or we go out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll think about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Real good date, Joe. Remind me to take her out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .S.U. CAMPUS - MORNING Opening day of school. We take CUTS of students arriving, football players checking out the new girls from atop the wall of the athletic dorm, Louanne and Autumn greeting returning sisters at the sorority, students registering for classes etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell sits across from WILLIAM SMITH, Academic Advisor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell is clearly deflated by this painful indication of his academic standing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Darnell, I've reviewed your placement test and I'm afraid you failed to meet our entrance requirements in two areas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does that mean? I can't play football?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. It means you're going to have to take some remedial classes, what we call "zero level" courses. Specifically Math 0 and English 0.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't get college credit for them, but they will help you prepare to take the Placement Test again at the end of the quarter. If you pass at that time you'll be able to officially enter the university and take college level courses. You'll still be able to take an American History survey course, but it won't count on your record until you pass the Placement Test. But first things first. To start, I'm approving a tutor for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A tutor? I don't need no tutor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any tutor. And yes you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A meeting of the football brain trust; Coach Winters, Athletic Director, GALEN HOWARD, a publicist, SHARON BRAVER, and the Sports Information Director (S.I.D.) LARRY NICHOLS. Also present is Joe Kane, somewhat discomfited at being the center of all this attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe is increasingly uneasy with all this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If Joe was uneasy before, he's overwhelmed now. He tries not to show it. After all, who could turn down a Heisman campaign? Still it's a megaton of pressure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nichols holds up a black CAMPAIGN BUTTON with the phrase "Kane is Able" enblazoned on it in gold letters. This gets a rise out of everyone except Joe, who's still not sure about all this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think both Joe and the university are best served by a straightforward Heisman campaign. Nothing too gimmicky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've compiled a mailing list of around 1300 opinion makers; newspapers, football writers, and sports anchors. First we send them a packet on Joe and his achievements. Bio, stats, plus human interest stuff; commitment to academics, charity work, etc. Then we update it each week with a postcard. Heisman voters hate opening envelopes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't really done any charity work...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna start. We've got some things lined up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unfortunately, because we weren't in the top 20 last year, we only have one network T.V. game to give Joe national exposure. Although it's a good one; Michigan. But we'll also be taping all our other games and buying satellite time. That way we can produce our own highlight package and interview pieces and send them out to T.V. stations all over the country for their sportscasts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any questions, Joe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, no... I just... you really think I got a shot to win this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, yes. Plus it's a good thing for the program. Publicizes the school, gives a boost to recruiting, and it's a great thing for you. Jumps up your draft position, the size of your first contract, everything. It's a hell of an opportunity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All you gotta do is back it up on the field, and we have no doubts about that, cause we know "Kane is Able."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Joe lies on his bed, staring up at the ceiling, unable to get to sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone rings. Camille, who's been asleep, rolls over and answers it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This is Joe Kane. What did you decide?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (still drowsy) What? (looking at the clock) It's 3:00 in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanta know what you decided.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I couldn't think of any other sports I could beat you at.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I'll pick you up tonight at 6:00.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Autumn sits at a tutorial table, looking at her notes. She becomes aware of someone approaching. She looks up to see Darnell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Autumn looks back to where Darnell is pointing. Sure enough, SCOTT SHERMAN is hard at work with another Tutor. Autumn can't believe it. She tries to compose herself. Darnell sits down across the table from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell is genuinely hurt by this dose of reality. His customary bravado melts away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Autumn, disarmed by his sudden humility, has no real rebuttal. She would have had to tutor him anyway, but now she's having trouble being angry about it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Autumn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Darnell. What are you doin here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My advisor says I need a tutor. Ya know, just to get me over a couple rough spots. (showing her a paper) I saw your name on this list. I figured if you couldn't keep my attention, nobody could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Darnell, but I've already been assigned. You're gonna have to find somebody else. I'm tutoring Scott Sherman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not anymore. I asked Coach Winters to switch us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coach Winters wouldn't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh he would. I'm a bigger prospect than Sherman. (pointing across the way) He's a lineman on the scout team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon Autumn, you could teach me some real erudition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to whisper, pissed) Will you stop using those big words. It sounds ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (serious about this) What doya mean? I'm improvin' myself. I learn a new word out of the dictionary every day. Mendacious, pejorative, antithetical, commensurate...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you don't ever use them right. Pretending to be smart is not the same as being educated. Or erudite. It's just a con. And it makes you sound stupid, no matter how big a prospect you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .K... even more reason for you to be my tutor. You already taught me something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At another table, looking distracted and bored as his TUTOR reads his history assignment to him. Alvin takes out a walkman and puts the headphones on. WE HEAR A HORN BEEP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille comes out the front door, summoned by the horn. She stops at the sight of something. We REVERSE TO REVEAL Joe on his Harley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out a motorcycle helmet toward her, daring her. She burns, but her competitiveness makes it impossible for her to decline this challenge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe smiles and kicks the starter. Camille climbs on and they roar off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We goin' on that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh. I thought we might take a ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I promised my dad I'd never get on one of those.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you, one of these trust- fund princesses? It's fine for me to play a game I don't know, but I ask you to try somethin' different and you hide behind your daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snatching the helmet) All right. But we go slow. No cowboy stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Just outside town. Joe and Camille come down the highway at moderate speed. Camille's hanging on for dear life, but we can tell she's enjoying it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe immediately accelerates, throwing Camille's head back. Her SHRIEK is lost in the whine of the engine, as they speed away from camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They approach a high-banked turn, beyond which appears to be a long, sheer dropoff. Joe looks back at Camille, smiles devilishly, not looking where he's going. Camille sees they're heading straight for the edge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too late. Joe brakes, fishtails, but goes over the top of the bank, off the edge, flying out into oblivion, Camille screaming.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This speed, o.k.?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Slow down, damnit. Joe... Joe!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (freaked) Joe, look out!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As it plops down onto a wide LEDGE not visible from the road, three feet below the top of the bank. Joe lands it, skids to a professional stop, breaks into raucous laughter. Camille jumps off the bike, scared stiff and livid with anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camille's ready to throttle him, then something catches her ear. Sure enough, there are SEVERAL DOGS BARKING in the distance. Joe smiles at her. She looks away, still angry, but amused in spite of herself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How could you do that, you stupid punk? It isn't funny, god-dammit, you coulda killed us! You're crazy, you know that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it easy. I've done that a hundred times. No big deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeh? Then why are you shaking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) I don't know... I guess cause I've never done it with someone else on the bike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just wanted to scare me. Are you happy now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, pretty much. And the scream was even better than I thought it'd be. Every dog within hearing distance wants to mate with you now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Working class, sawdust floor, George Thoroughgood's "Who Do You Love" on the jukebox. Camille and Joe are sitting in a booth. Joe putting away the beers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You come here a lot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now and then. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not exactly a campus favorite. This is almost like hidin' out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like places where nobody knows me. This too low-rent for you?

dialogue.raw_text: No, my dad owned a place like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your dad? You mean he owned a chain of these?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not everybody with a Southern accent has their own plantation. My dad could never afford to send me here. I learned to play tennis on public courts. Mighta been able to play pro someday, if I hadn't hurt my knee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you're just a scholarship jock like me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh. You disappointed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what we're doin' here? Goin' out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. What doya think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're crazy for jeopardizing your scholarship and a pro future by jumping motorcycles off of highways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just tryin' to keep my edge, Camille. The other guys look to me cause they think I'll do anything. I lose that, I'm just another guy, and we all get our ass kicked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Joe. You scare me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The keys.

direction.raw_text: Autumn's anger melts away in the face of this painful truth.

direction.raw_text: Autumn knows this is no line. He means it. She's seeing him with new eyes. Moved by his pain, engaged by his sincerity, and more than a little taken by his regard for her.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was always workin'. Usually two jobs. Comin' home one night she stopped to get us some root beer. Got caught in a gang crossfire. Shot three times... died on the way to the hospital. You want me to write about that?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I started hangin' with the J.B.M., gang-bangin'... Did some time in the Hall. Reverand Wallace saw me playin' football on a juvenile probation team. Took me in, got me into high school. Only reason they accepted me was 'cause I could play football. Sorta like here. Football saved my life. I'd be nowhere without football.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then... maybe you could write about football this once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, o.k... thanks. (pause) I've seen a lotta shitty things in my life, Autumn. That's why I know when I see somethin' good.

direction.raw_text: Autumn's pointing out a figure on a graph in Darnell's math book. As she explains, Darnell leans close to kiss her. Autumn quickly leans away, glances around to see if anyone saw Darnell's attempt. Darnell laughs.

direction.raw_text: A group of football players sits in the back of the class. As the HISTORY PROFESSOR lectures at the board, Darnell furiously takes notes. Scott Sherman, seizing the opportunity, leans forward from the desk behind him and pokes the football out of Darnell's left hand. Darnell, Scott and two other FRESHMAN FOOTBALL PLAYERS spring out of their seats, scrambling after the loose ball. The prof and the other students watch appalled as Darnell and the others dive under chairs and overturn desks in pursuit of the elusive ball. Finally, Darnell, winded and disheveled, comes up with it. He and the others quickly return to their seats. The prof looks at Darnell aghast.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry... I lost my football.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Joe and Camille are locked up in a furious game of raquetball. Joe makes a wicked kill shot on the last point, and pumps a fist in triumph. Camille, pissed at losing, throws her racket and stomps around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darnell and Autumn are having a daytime tutoring session on a secluded patch of lawn. Darnell holds his football. As he begins to read aloud from East of Eden, Autumn pokes the ball out of his hand. They both scramble for it, Darnell winding up slightly on top of her. They eye each other a beat. Darnell bends down to kiss her. She lets herself kiss him for a second, then gets up and starts to collect her books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Several of the players are gathered around a bulletin board in the hall. The starting lineup for the first game has been posted. Darnell traces his finger from the designation TAILBACK over to the name RAY GRIFFEN. He drops his eyes, obviously disappointed. Lattimer, meanwhile, is checking the defensive board. He finds his name posted as a starting defensive end. Punching the air, he dashes out of the building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!! Starting defense. Place at the table. Whooo!! Yes!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lattimer, in his euphoria, races out into the lot, and begins head-butting car windows. He breaks out three in a row, and yells in triumph, his forehead dripping blood. Winters, walking with the TEAM TRAINER, has seen this from across the street. He knows there's something dark at work here.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .C.A.A. is gonna test half the team before the game Saturday. Make sure Lattimer knows about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: END

direction.raw_text: The chairs are arranged in several circles, ten players to a circle, like a bunch of formalized huddles. Coach Winters addresses the assembly.

dialogue.raw_text: As the veteran players know, we have Pride Night every year before our opening game. It's a chance to get to know each other better, share some thoughts, and bring us closer together as a team. So to start off, I'd like each player to tell the others in his group what he likes best about football and then what he's most proud of off the field. I've asked some of the seniors to lead it off. Gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I don't know... It's the battle. The goin' to war with the other guys. Hangin' together.

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Bein' different from everybody else. Havin' our own dorm, stayin' in hotels the night before games. Settin' ourselves apart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Havin' a chance to be somebody. To do somethin' that people look up to you for. Your strength and your courage. Not everybody can play football. We're the lucky ones.

direction.raw_text: The thing I'm most proud of myself for?

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Just that I'm here. That I'm not dead or in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The great thing about football is you can lose yourself in it.

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There's no time to think, to worry, to have doubts. Everything else fades away. You just move and react.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The best thing is when you dominate. That feeling when you hit a guy real good, really stick him, and you hear that little moan.

direction.name: direction

The ball is snapped. The quarterback pitches to the tailback as Alvin charges into the hole, screaming at the top of his lungs. The tailback, eyes wide with fear, cuts back, away from Alvin, where he's promptly crunched by Lattimer. The ball flies loose, there's a scramble, Alvin comes up with it. E.S.U. ball.

direction.raw_text: Joe hits the 4 count, and the ball is snapped. Bud Lite and the Big Tackle fire out. Bud drives a forearm into the stomach of the Black Tackle, doubling him over. The Black Tackle comes back, slamming a forearm up under Bud's chin, snapping his neck back. Joe, meanwhile, fades to pass, pump fakes, steps up. Bud Lite, chicken fighting the Black Tackle, sticks his fingers in the Tackle's eyes, then cut-blocks him to the ground. The Tackle falls on Bud, and smashes a fist into his ribs. Bud rolls him over. Joe spots his flanker back, MAURICE WARD, on a flag pattern. Lofts a perfect spiral to him in the corner of the endzone. Touchdown. The crowd goes wild, as Bud Lite pushes off the Black Tackle's throat getting up from the pile. Joe pumps a fist in the air, hugs Ward, as the team celebrates. MUSIC BEGINS.

dialogue.raw_text: Now let's turn to our Heisman watch.
